item.title: How to Save In Oblivion Remastered
item.description:
Upon finishing the tutorial in The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion Remastered , players can go out and explore the different cities and areas, but they must not forget to save their progress constantly. Like most RPGs, the game is filled with branching dialogues, important decisions, and combat encounters that can impact your experience. In these moments, Manual Saves and Autosaves become essential tools to prevent unwanted setbacks or to retry alternate outcomes .

While the Autosave feature is useful, relying on it alone isn’t always enough. Manual saving gives players full control over their progress, especially before risky scenarios. Knowing how the saving system works—and using it wisely—can make your journey through Cyrodiil much smoother. This guide offers information on how saving works in The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion Remastered .

How to Save In Oblivion Remastered

Right after you complete the character creation and your playthrough commences, you will have the option to save the game from that point onwards . To do so, you must open your journal and navigate all the way to the right to the System tab. It is here that you can save your game or load an existing save file. As the game also supports Quicksave, you can use that in case you don't want to go through the process of saving . On PC, you can Quicksave by pressing the F5 button on your keyboard. Do keep in mind that there is only one Quicksave, so making a new one will overwrite the previous one.

You can also use the "save [name]" console command on PC, which allows you to create a save file with your chosen text.

Despite the Quicksave coming in handy at times, it is best not to rely heavily on the feature and stick with manual saving throughout the game. The game provides a lot of save files, so you don't have to worry about running out anytime soon. The game also supports an Autosave feature, which has five slots that get overwritten when a new one pops up.

When Does Oblivion Remastered Autosave?

Autosaving in The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion Remastered occurs quite often, giving players a reliable fallback if they mess up haggling with an NPC, accidentally kill someone, or just want to undo a poor decision. The game autosaves every time you enter or exit a building, dungeon , or landmark, which helps maintain progress during exploration. It also autosaves when you fast travel or sleep in a bed .

item.title: Switch 2 Pre-Orders Are Hitting 'Historic Levels'
item.description:
Summary

  • A French retailer reports that pre-order sales for the Nintendo Switch 2 have reached 'historic' levels.
  • The console is slated to be released on June 5.
  • Pre-orders begin in the US at midnight on April 24.

A leading French retailer has revealed that Nintendo Switch 2 console and accessory sales have already been selling incredibly well, hitting "historic" levels. Many have worried that the introduction of United States tariffs and impacts on global markets would negatively impact upcoming video game releases and console sales, but it would seem the Nintendo Switch 2 is managing to find early success, at least in France.

Presently slated to launch on June 5, the Nintendo Switch 2 will be the latest console from the Japanese gaming juggernaut. The new hardware quickly sparked enthusiasm among audiences with its graphics and performance improvements over its predecessor, and the reveal of upcoming Switch 2 games like Mario Kart World and Donkey Kong Bananza have seen many players looking to secure pre-orders for the new console. This fan hype seems to be holding true, as one major retailer has already revealed that the Nintendo Switch 2 console orders are off to an impressive start.

While speaking to the French technology news outlet Frandroid, Charlotte Massicault, director of multimedia and gaming for French retailer Fnac, stated that pre-orders for the Nintendo Switch 2 have hit a "historic level." Massicault noted that the opening weekend sales after the April 2 Nintendo Switch 2 Direct were "completely crazy" and that the hotly debated pricing of the upcoming consoles was seemingly "not a barrier." She further revealed that the hardware accessories for the Nintendo Switch 2 have also been selling well, with the Nintendo Switch 2 Camera boasting surprising sales numbers, and confirmed that the Mario Kart World bundle version of the console was receiving the most interest from consumers.

Nintendo Switch 2 Sales Continue to Rise Despite Pricing

While there has been backlash to the Nintendo Switch 2 game pricing model, it would seem that audiences are still excitedly locking in their pre-orders for the console. It is key to note that French pre-orders for the Nintendo Switch 2 opened as early as April 2, the same day as the console's dedicated Direct, but pre-orders in the United States and other regions will not begin until midnight on April 24. Whether the US pre-orders will hit a similarly "historic level" as those revealed by Fnac remains to be seen, but the early numbers coming out of France seem to bode well for the Nintendo Switch 2.

The original Nintendo Switch is one of the best-selling video game consoles of all time, ranking number one in the United States and number two internationally, just behind the PlayStation 2. If the Nintendo Switch 2 can overcome the economic barriers ahead, it could potentially join its predecessor as one of the most successful consoles in gaming history. Interested fans can stay tuned for more updates on the Nintendo Switch 2 pre-sales and more details leading up to and following the console's launch.

item.title: RuneScape: Dragonwilds - How To Make Loom Harness
item.description:
At the beginning of their journey in Ashenfall, RuneScape: Dragonwilds players will learn how to craft various basic items, such as Threads. Later on, these common threads can be enhanced into other items. For example, using a Coarse Thread on the Loom will create a Rough Cloth.

However, as players progress into the game, they will soon require an item called Padded Cloth in RuneScape: Dragonwilds . While it may seem like there’s no way to craft it, the main key to making it is to first obtain a Loom Harness in RuneScape: Dragonwilds , which is the upgraded version of the Loom, similar to how the Tannery can be enhanced using the Tanner’s Kit Improvement.

How To Make A Loom Harness In RuneScape: Dragonwilds

To make a Loom harness in RuneScape: Dragonwilds , you need to smelt an Iron Bar and interact with the Loom structure (or build a Loom, if you haven't yet). That will unlock Loom Harness, which is a structure that can upgrade the Loom Harness. You have to build the Loom Harness right next to the Loom structure to link both of them together.

What Does Loom Harness Do?

Loom initially turns Thread into Cloth . You can insert Coarse and Wool Threads into the Loom facility to create Rough and Wool Clothes. With a Loom Harness, you get an additional crafting slot , allowing your character to combine Rough and Wool Clothes into Padded Clothes.

How To Use Padded Cloth

Padded Cloth is an essential material for a variety of armor sets you can craft using the Smithing Anvil. Here are some of the armors you can make using the Padded Cloth in RuneScape: Dragonwilds :

Item

Recipe

Dark Mage Hood

  • 1 Silver Bar
  • 3 Padded Cloth
  • 2 Hard Leather
  • 1 Vault Shard

Dark Mage Robes

  • 4 Silver Bar
  • 8 Padded Cloth
  • 8 Hard Leather
  • 3 Vault Shard

Dark Mage Robe Legs

  • 2 Silver Bar
  • 6 Padded Cloth
  • 4 Hard Leather
  • 2 Vault Shard

Dragonkin Mage Hood

  • 1 Gold Bar
  • 3 Hard Leather
  • 2 Padded Cloth
  • 1 Vault Shard

Dragonkin Mage Robes

  • 4 Gold Bar
  • 10 Hard Leather
  • 6 Padded Cloth
  • 3 Vault Shard

Dragonkin Mage Robe Legs

  • 2 Gold Bar
  • 6 Hard Leather
  • 4 Padded Cloth
  • 2 Vault Shard

Wild Archer Cowl

  • 2 Gold Bar
  • 4 Hard Leather
  • 2 Padded Cloth
  • 1 Vault Shard

Wild Archer Body

  • 4 Gold Bar
  • 12 Hard Leather
  • 4 Padded Cloth
  • 3 Vault Shard

Wild Archer Chaps

  • 4 Gold Bar
  • 8 Hard Leather
  • 3 Padded Cloth
  • 2 Vault Shard

Paladin's Helm

  • 6 Iron Bar

  • 1 Padded Cloth
  • 1 Vault Shard

Paladin's Platebody

  • 2 Padded Cloth

item.title: How to Fast Travel in Clair Obscur Expedition 33
item.description:
While Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 does not feature an extremely expansive fast travel system, there are opportunities for players to instantly warp between certain locations. Those opportunities arise when exploring the game's discrete maps, allowing players to quickly move around the Spring Meadows, Flying Waters, and beyond. This guide is here to elaborate upon that system, and it will give players a solid understanding of how fast travel works in Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 .

How to Fast Travel in Clair Obscur Expedition 33

The world of Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 is split into two parts: discrete, linear maps and a semi-open world (the Continent) that is used to move between those maps. The game's preliminary discrete maps include the Spring Meadows, Flying Waters, and Ancient Sanctuary, and players will use the Continent to access their entry portals.

With respect to fast travel, it can only be done on discrete maps , like the ones that have just been mentioned. More specifically, fast travel can only be used to move between the Expedition Flags that a player has already visited on those maps. For full clarity, Expedition Flags are, essentially, checkpoints at which Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 players can rest, upgrade their attributes, and learn skills, and they will encounter them as they work their way through discrete maps.

Once a player has visited at least two Expedition Flags on a discrete map in Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 , they will find that a "Fast Travel" option is available when interacting with a Flag. Selecting that option will bring up a list of all the Flags that the player has activated on the current map, and they can click on one to be instantly transported to it.

Players will ultimately unlock a feature that allows them to instantly travel from any Expedition Flag to the Continent.

Fast Traveling Between Maps in Clair Obscur Expedition 33

While Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 does not allow players to instantly travel between discrete maps, they can easily move between them via the Continent. Indeed, the portals that are used to access locations like the Flying Waters and Ancient Sanctuary are almost always accessible from the overworld map, allowing players to easily revisit locations whenever doing so is of interest.

Furthermore, it does not actually take very long to move across the Continent, despite how big it may seem when looking at its map. Players will also unlock mechanics and pathways that allow them to cross the Continent even more quickly as they continue their time with Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 . While this increased speed never quite rivals the instantaneous teleportation that a comprehensive fast travel system would support, players should find that it is not very difficult to traverse the continent without one.

item.title: Best Birthsigns For Dark Elf In Oblivion Remastered, Ranked
item.description:
Like any good RPG, The Elder Scrolls: Oblivion Remaster is known for having a pretty diverse character customizer that allows for both a wide range of cosmetic options and choices, but also character backgrounds and races that augment the gameplay in unique and interesting ways. One of the most important decisions when creating a character is the birthsign that represents the star sign of the character, and each provides its own set of buffs, bonuses, and even some spells to start the player's adventure off in a different way.

An iconic race in the Elder Scrolls franchise is the Dunmer, also known as Dark Elves. The starting stats and abilities that the Dunmer have are pretty great, with some built-in fire resistance and skill bonuses that affect both blade weapons and destructive magic. This makes the race a pretty great all-around choice that has a good amount of versatility and gives the player a lot of choice over the kind of build they can make. Whether magic or swords, the Dark Elf is a great starter class to set the player off on an adventure with some decent power and bonuses to prevent them from falling too early.

5 The Lady

Simplistic Power That Never Feels Weak

  • Effect: +10 Willpower, +10 Endurance

For players seeking a resilient and dependable character build, look no further than the Lady birthsign. Offering substantial benefits through bonuses to Willpower and Endurance, attributes that are critical for both survivability and sustained performance in prolonged battles, the sign adds a significant bonus to the player's resilience in combat, as well as their ability to pump out spells as and when they need to. Dark Elves, who already possess a balanced stat distribution, can use these additional bonuses to become incredibly difficult to kill, thriving both in the thick of battle and in prolonged magical engagements.

The Lady's bonuses encourage a versatile playstyle that blends magic and melee without overcommitting to one discipline, which can often be the downfall of some of the other sign choices. Dark Elves under this sign will find themselves able to recover quickly from damage, control fights more easily with sustained spell use, and endure attacks that would stagger less durable builds. Although The Lady does not directly boost offensive capabilities and doesn't come with any flashy spells or abilities, being able to keep a strong defense while still casting reliably makes it an excellent choice for players who want to stay in the fight longer.

4 The Warrior

For When The Spells Just Aint Cutting It

  • +10 Strength, +10 Endurance

The Warrior birthsign grants a straightforward but powerful bonus, increasing both Strength and Endurance by ten points each, which is a pretty substantial buff to have at the start of the game. The boost to melee damage and overall survivability is incredibly valuable for any class, and for Dark Elves, who naturally possess balanced physical and magical abilities, this birthsign shifts their potential firmly toward physical dominance without entirely discarding their magical utility. It is an excellent choice for players intending to build a frontline combatant who can endure punishment and dish out significant damage with every strike, thriving in close-quarters battles where precision and resilience are key.

Choosing The Warrior encourages an aggressive, weapon-focused playstyle, where swords, axes, and heavy armor take precedence over spellcasting, whilst not sacrificing the ability to multi-class in any way. Dark Elves benefit uniquely from this approach, as their agility and speed allow them to be quicker and more evasive than traditional heavy fighters, while the bonuses from the sign give them the necessary raw power to match any opponent toe-to-toe. It might not be a mage's best friend when it comes to stat buffs, but for a Dark Elf looking to get up close and personal, it's a pretty solid choice that doesn't inhibit the player's ability to swap into another playstyle later on.

3 The Mage

Any Spellcasters Dream

  • Effect:+50 Magicka

When building a character with the intent of utilizing powerful spells and overwhelming enemies with a wide variety of magical effects, few attributes are as valuable as pure Magicka. The Mage birthsign grants a flat +50 bonus to Magicka, with not a single downside, giving players a significant edge early on when spells are costly and magical stamina is at a premium. The bonus makes the sign an ideal choice for characters who plan to weave destruction, conjuration, or restoration heavily into their core gameplay, and Dark Elves with their innate fire resistance and balanced attributes are uniquely poised to benefit from the flexibility this sign offers, blending both offensive and defensive magic with ease.

Choosing the Mage birthsign enhances the hybrid potential of the Dark Elf, encouraging a playstyle where spellcasting is a primary tool without sacrificing effectiveness in melee combat. The freedom to sit back and throw an onslaught of spells, only to swap to a hefty sword to cut down anyone who gets too close, feels amazing and takes away any restrictions that other signs may have. Furthermore, this abundance of Magicka synergizes well with enchantment-focused gameplay, allowing for a heavier reliance on charged weapons and magical items and granting the player a powerful foundation from the earliest stages of the game.

2 The Thief

Stealth And Elf Go Hand-In-Hand

  • Effect: +10 Agility, +10 Speed, +10 Luck

Elves are known for being cunning and sneaky, so it makes perfect sense for a stealth player to choose this birthsign to play into the stereotype as perfectly as possible. The Thief provides bonuses to three essential attributes, each of which influences core aspects of the game like map traversal and skill effectiveness, which can be invaluable in more situations than just stealth. For Dark Elves, who are naturally inclined toward agile, stealth-oriented builds, the birthsign amplifies these strengths, offering a swift and elusive playstyle perfect for those who prefer hit-and-run tactics, assassination, or infiltration.

It also encourages a highly mobile and tactical style of gameplay where positioning and timing are paramount and turns the game into less of an action RPG and more of a true stealth game. Dark Elves under this sign excel at striking from the shadows, evading pursuit, and exploiting enemy weaknesses with precise attacks, and the added effectiveness that comes innately from attacking from the shadows more than makes up for the lack of direct damage buffs the sign provides. Coupled with the Dark Elf’s built-in resistance and balanced attribute pool, The Thief allows for the creation of an exceptionally deadly and unpredictable character no matter the setting.

1 The Apprentice

The True Magical Glass Canon Experience

  • Effect: +100 Magicka, 100% weakness to Magicka

An incredibly powerful sign with an equally incredible drawback, The Apprentice offers one of the most dramatic increases to Magicka in the game, whilst also making the player highly susceptible to enemy mages. This makes it a double-edged choice that can lead to either overwhelming power or catastrophic failure, depending on how the character is built and played. For Dark Elves, who already benefit from a natural 75% resistance to fire, this trade-off can be partially mitigated, and makes the downside a little less suffocating than with other races.

The Apprentice encourages a high-risk, high-reward playstyle where powerful spellcasting capabilities are prioritized above all else, and every decision when taking on stronger magic users needs to be taken with care and caution. Dark Elves utilizing this sign will find that they can unleash all manner of powerful spells far earlier than other characters, giving them a massive advantage against conventional enemies. And as the traditional mage playstyle is already fairly safe, the drawback basically disappears for large portions of the game, and is non-existent against the long list of melee enemies that players will encounter. For players willing to embrace the risks, The Apprentice enables a Dark Elf to become one of the most dangerous and explosive forces in the entire game and offers a level of power from the start that is pretty hard to beat.

6 Images
6 Images
